blogs.title:
Jerry's Bizzare Adventure:
A Month-Long Trip Home
blogs.name: triphome
blogs.summary: Jerry's Bizzare Adventure: A Month-Long Trip Home...
brief: After 3 consecutive years without returning home in China due to the pandemic, this summer I have to go back due to some family and personal reasons. For the first time in a while, I could reunite with my family and enjoy this summer with them.

It is definitely not an ideal time to go back. Another wave of COVID outbreak (the Omicron varient) have just hit, and major cities like Shanghai had been locked down for weeks. Amidst of all these chaos, my month-long trip back home began...

content.source: This blog records my journey from U.S. to China in summer 2022. By writing down what I see and hear during this unique adventure, I wish to share some insight of the impact of COVID in China. This is not intended to be a detailed instruction for traveling to China in 2022, please refer to official resources if you are making plans. But I do hope it provides some advice for those who are going to China in the near future.

It wasn't until mid April when I was told to fly back to China. Long story in short, we was informed to schedule an in-person interview for immigration with the U.S. Consulate. Despite all the uncertainties (from China's COVID regulations), we still decided to get this thing done because we have already postponed the interview the previous year.

Thanks to China's circuit breaker arrangement for international flights, tickets are extremely hard to purchase. We ended up resorting to a group ticket scalper who managed to get me a ticket on May 13<sup>th</sup> at a price around $10,000. The price is not much higher than buying directly from airline companies, but is still absolutely insane comparing to summer 2019 (pre-COVID) when I flew round-trip for under $2,000.

The policy for international travelers in China require us to "self-quarantine" the week prior to flying in the departure city. So here we are, after finishing my last final in the noon, I hurried to farwell my roommate (who is graduating this semester) and hopped on a flight to San Francisco, the first stop of this journey.

content.description: Me at Hartsfield airport, Atlanta. Shot by my roommate.

content.source: Upon arrival in San Francisco, a friend of mine picked me up and we headed straight to a Korean BBQ for dinner. We didn't hang out late since he had a final the next day. I settled done in a Hilton hotel next to the airport and began my one week self-quarantine.

The Chinese government also require international travelers to get tested for COVID during self-quarantine, and they only approve test results from two specified institutions. Without a better choice, I booked the 3 required tests (an antigen test 1 week before flying, a blood test 5 days later, and another antigen and antibody test within 24 hours before boarding) with Apostle Diagnotics for $650.

The next few days I had been chilling in the hotel room to reduce the risk of being infected. Other than going to the COVID test place, I was watching YouTube and animes or playing video games most of the time. Luckily my friends in San Francisco offered to drive me to lunch and dinner, saving me from the embarrassment of ordering take outs everyday.

content.description: A Japanese Izakaya and a Chinese restuarant we went to during my self-quarantine

content.source: We also visited Japantown the day before departure and spent the afternoon in a book store. I bought several mangas and light novels to kill time on the airplane and during the quarantine after landing.

content.description: The book store in Japantown

content.source: The Chinese governments have recently lowered the boarding rate of inbounding international flights furthur to 40%, (before this rate was 75%) which indicates airline companies have oversold tickets and they must kick many people off the plane. I heard from the grapevine that my ticket was purchased at a high price hence will be kept with high priority, the outcome also supported this argument. However, it was still really frustrating hearing other travelers' tickets get cancelled from the group chat...

My last COVID test came out the afternoon before departure. I uploaded all test results along with some other documents (travel history form, personal health monitoring form, and letter of commitment on COVID-19 vaccination) to the Chinese Consulate via WeChat mini app. Later that day they issued me a blue health QR code that is valid for only 48 hours. (The health QR code is ubiquiously used in China for the government to track down COVID infected and close contacts, green code stands for safe, yellow for in risk of close contact, red for infected and blue for special situations like international travelers)

content.description: Blue health code.

content.source: The long-waited departure day has come. The flight was at 11:00 am but I woke up around 5:00 because of both anxiety and excitement. We were notified the previous night for a change in the airplane model (from boeing 777-300er to 200er), meaning there will be even less seats. Unsure of whether the airline company will proceed to kick more people off, I thought it would be safer to get to the airport as early as possible in case they reserve seats in a first come first serve order. After all, until the moment I board the airplane, everything was still up in the air.

The airport have a dedicated area for people traveling to China and Korea. (both countries have very strict COVID regulation) It was before 6:00 am but many people are already in the line. (maybe they held the same suspicion as I did) I showed the staff at counter my ticket, passport, blue QR code and other required documents for check in. The rest was as normal, baggage check-in, security checks... (at this point going through these procedures in an ordinary way feels a bit unnatural for me)

content.description: An area dedicated for people traveling to China and Korea in SFO airport, shot at 6:00 am

content.source: While waiting at the gate, several people got called by the airport staff. Based on the few words I overheard from their conversation, it sounds like those people were kicked off. Other passengers were like lambs to be slaughtered. But fortunately, my ticket survived once again...

It is finally time to board. The counter staff checked our documents once again before we were allowed to board the airplane. Since the boarding rate was only 40%, I had much more space than I normally would have. I was the only one in a 4-seat row in the middle column of the economic class, so I was free to lay down and stretch anytime during the flight, making the 15 hours flights not so hard to endure. (guess that justifies the price of my ticket)

content.description: Onboard the airplane

content.source: After a 15-hour-long flight, (with an 1-hour intermediate stop at the Seoul airport for a change of flight attendences) we have landed in Shanghai Pudong Airport approximately 6:00 pm local time. We remained seated for another half an hour for medical stuffs to come aboard and sanitize every corner. After that we were called row by row to leave the airplane.

Our plane was the only passenger airplane arriving that afternoon, and it was quite astonishing especially that I had seen how busy PVG airport used to be. Most part of the airport (duty-free stores, restuarants, etc) had been shut down, and I could literally taste the glomminess in the air. It was as if I was adventuring in a building abandoned for years, just like in those scenes in horror movies. Sadly we were not allowed to take any pictures in the airport for whatever reasons the government was concerned of.

I showed them the documents I prepared pre-departure, and filled in several other questionnairs at the customs. My body temperature was taken before I was permitted to the counter. The entry inspection took much longer than it used to be, the inspector asked me several seemingly unnecessary questions relating to my F-1 visa and my college in U.S..

The next procedure was another COVID test. I was guided to a temporary bungalow outside the airport for the test. It was my very first nosal swab, and it was a very unpleasant experience. Essentially a straw-like collector was inserted so deeply into my nose that I could feel it grinding within my throat. Then after spinning a few times the it was slowly pull out, and it feels like my soul had also been dragged out along with the collector.

Following the COVID test, I was taken to an place to wait for the bus to the quarantine hotel. At this point I had to say goodbye to the friends I made during self-quarantine in San Francisco because the waiting area is divided based on our destination provinces. The quarantine policy differs between each provinces, for mine (Zhejiang) we got to choose between two quarantine plans: 14 days in Shanghai, or 3 days in Shanghai plus 11 days in another city in Zhejiang. I went with the later one since all the rumors about shortage of daily necessities in Shanghai.

content.description: Waiting areas for buses to the quarantine hotel

content.source: The bus took me and other 20 people who picked the same quarantine plan to a hotel in the border of Shanghai and Zhejiang Province. It was almost 11:00 pm when we arrived at the hotel. It took another hour to register, same information were collected yet again (I was asked to provide information like my passport number, ID number, street addresses, etc. at lease 5 times after landing in Shanghai, which for me just showcases how messy and inefficient the governments are arranging things) After paying the deposit, (yes, we pay the hotel fees ourselves, eventhough no one wants to be quarantined) the medical stuff sprayed disinfectant all over me and my luggages before I was guided to my room.

content.description: The hotel room for my first 3 days of quarantine. The carpet was covered by a layer of tape for hygiene purposes.

content.source: It's almost midnight when I get to the room. Each room has a chair next to the door outside, for the purpose of exchanging resources. I also received a "quarantine package" containing sanitizers, disinfectants and a themometer. We were instructed to take body temperature twice a day at specified times and put the thermometer on the chair outside for them to take records.

The next morning I woke up around 5 because of jetlag. There are already medical stuffs roaming around in the hallway. (in fact there are people patrolling 24/7 so it was impossible to sneak out) I got another nosal swab COVID test done around 6 and had breakfast at 7.

content.description: First morning in Shanghai, China.

content.source: The meals seems to be served by the cafe in the hotel, and delivered to the chair outside the room door. We were only allowed to open doors when meals are served or when medical stuffs knock at our doors to monitor our status. Other than that a siren would ring if we open the door and medical stuffs would immediately come to your door to see what's happening.
Early morning in the 4<sup>th</sup> day in Shanghai, we set off for Jiaxing, Zhejiang, to get quarantined for another 11 days. We were called to checkout and board the bus one at a time.

After an hour or-so of bus ride, we are dropped of in Jiaxing. We went through the same registration process, and the medical stuffs once again sprayed disinfectants all over me and my luggages. The hotel room is a little smaller this time, with a somewhat retro-style decoration.

The set up was pretty much the same as the previous quarantine hotel: a table next to the door to exchange resources except this time the medical stuff would come to our doors to measure body temperatures twice a day. Meals were delivered in similar fashion, but were ordered as takeout from a local restuarant instead.

I had VPN set up before departure so I could still accesss YouTube and many other webites that is blocked in China. I also started consuming the light novels bought in Japantown back in San Francisco. Once I get into things I enjoy, 11 days doesn't feel like too long of a period not being to go outside.

Another 11 days had passed. 14 days after landing in China, I am finally heading home! Just like last time, we were called out of our room one by one to check out the hotel and board the bus. I arrived home right around lunch time, and my parents prepared a big reunion meal to welcome my return. Unfortunately, we still cannot enjoy this meal on the same table, because the quarantine policy still requires me to self-quarantine at home for another week. My health code was assigned yellow (risky), so technically at this point I am eligible to go out, but I would still not be able to enter any public areas like shopping malls or parks.

Immediately following my arrival, a worker from the neighborhood committee came to my house. He checked the room I will be self-quarantined at (the room must come with a bathroom because we will not be allowed to exit the bedroom door) and asked me to sign several other consents. (agreeements to install an electronic door lock, get tested for COVID and several other terms) After that, an electronic door lock was installed to the bedroom door, we were informed that this will send signal to the local police office, and everytime we open the door they will be notified.

The city I live in (Ningbo) has a comparably friendly quarantine policy where we are allowed to open doors  up to 10 times a day for food delivery and trash takeouts. However, it was still adviced to open the door as less often as possible, and if we break any rules, the local police department will make phone calls to give warning.

content.description: Looking out from the window from my home the afternoon I returned.

content.source: Medical stuffs came in the morning of the first and last day of the self-quarantine, my body temperature was recorded, and yet another two nosal swab tests was done. After all these days quarantined I finally got bored, but at least home is much more comfortable than hotels...

Another week has passed since I got home, and it's already more than a month since I departed Atlanta. My health code turned green after both nosal swab test resulted negative. The neighborhood committee sent another worker to remove the electronic door lock, and I am now free to go out. I sit on the same table with my parents and had lunch together for the first time in 3 long years, telling them stories of this bizzare adventure.

content.description: Me having lunch with my parents for the first time in 3 years.

content.source: Looking back at all the things I went through along the way, it was indeed a piece of unique and memorable experience. Although I encountered lots of problems, overall it went much more smoothly as I had expected. Now the real vacation lies ahead and I cannot wait to enjoy it. Hope everyone have a great summer and see y'all next time. Until then.

blogs.title: Mochi The British Shorthair
blogs.name: catimages
blogs.summary: Cat Images: Mochi The British Shorhair
brief: Celebrating the 2<sup>nd</sup> birthday of our British shorthair, Mochi, or you can call him by his Chinese name 点点 (Diǎn diǎn). Just want to take this chance to dump some images of our furry friend over the past year. It <del>theoretically</del> cures all types of depression and stress, so don't miss it. Enjoy!

content.source: Mochi, or by his Chinese name 点点 (Diǎn diǎn), is turning 2 years old today. It has been more than 1 and a half years since he joined our family.

content.description: Going on a travel!
Wanna play hide and seek with me?
Working out...
Selfie hahaha
Zzz...
With my friend Paopao

content.source: Credits to: Jonathan Zhang, Ivan Hou, Cody Sheng, Stephanie Jiang and Me

blogs.title: Fall Break & Lake House
blogs.name: lakehouse
brief: It is fall break, and that means we are half-way done for another stressful semester!
This time, my friend and I are heading north for a lakeside vacation. We spent the weekend in a lakehouse and also rented a yacht to relax on the lake. Lots of new experiences and lots of fun...

content.source: My friends had long been wishing for a lakehouse holiday, and it is happening this time, fall break 2021.

We set off the Saturday afternoon and it was almost dusk when we got to Lake Heartwell in northern Georgia. We had booked a yacht ahead of time and actually found a water route from the yacht rental place to our lakeside Airbnb, so we headed straigh to the dock. As we return along the waterway, we also had the fortune to enjoy sunset on the lake.

content.description: Sunset from the middle of the lake.

content.source: The next morning, we continued to sail on the lake for some sunshine.

content.description: We continued a day on yacht to enjoy some sunshine and had pizza for lunch on the lake.

content.source: Since the boater's license in our state only requires a driver's license and a boater's education, we all had a chance to operate the yacht. I also had my "yatch captain" experience: Are you ready, kid?

content.description: My first time as a yacht captain

content.source: We enjoyed the rest of the day on the lake and it was almost dark again when we returned home.

content.description: Sky gradually turning dark as we return along the waterway

content.source: After returning from the lake, we had a hotpot party for dinner.
We had bought some fireworks on the way the previous day, so after dinner we took a walk along the river to find a large open space to set those fireworks.
We also bought this thing called the Kongming lantern (Sky lantern), which is an old Chinese tradition to write ones' wishes on the lantern and send it airborne.

content.description: Us setting the lantern up and watch it rising to the sky.

content.source: The starry sky is crystal clear, we could even see the milky way with naked eyes.

The only thing that upset us was that nobody had a digital camera, so we only had our phones' default camera to take pictures of these beautiful stars, but at least the milky way is visible from the picture.

content.description: The milky way in the night sky

content.source: Anyways, what a trip! Tried lots of new things and had lots of fun with friends. Must be a fall break to be remembered.

blogs.title: Hello World
blogs.name: versionhistory
brief: A version history of my personal website, in the form of a log for major updates made in the past. Includes information like date of updates, description of major changes and snap shoots of old versions of website.
This log will be updated in the future when new features are added.

content.source: First version of my static portfolio website released on git page.
Changed the layout of skills section to display proficiency as progress bars.

Fixed a bug related to the loading animation of skills proficiency (progress) bar.
Improved the appearance of projects section and adds more detailed information in the introduction for each project.
Rebuilt the website with same layout and content using ReactJS and release the React version to git page.
Configured to host the website on WordPress, and hook the website under my custom domain name (the current URL).
Created a separated homepage from the rest of the portfolio website.

Moved two skills & education and projects gallery to two separated pages.
Improved the layout of project section.
Introduced a blog section to my personal website. Add past blogs I had kept otherwhere to this page.
Added a comment section under each blog.

Migrated website from WordPress to AWS Elastic Beanstalk.
Enabled HTTPS connection.
Created search function within the website. Key words will be searched in project and blog posts.
